Publish npm package for the browser (#1676)

* add reference to typescript declarations in package.json

* trim trailing whitespaces in package.json

* remove unnecessary optional flag in package-lock.json

* improve .npmignore (ignore everything but `LICENSE`, `README.md`, `VERSION`, `build/output/`, `extras/`, `package.json`, and `package-lock.json`)

* improve package.json keywords

* fix missing options in pc.Application parameter

* fix alternative type in pc.Keyboard parameter

* remove jsdom dependency (to avoid 8MB browser bundle)

* npmignore conf-api.json and conf-tsd.json (previously named tsd-jsdoc.conf)

Fix CubeMap Seams bug on A12 and A12X chips (#1465)

A12 and A12X chips (late 2018 iPhones and iPads) had a regression in their WebGL implementation which removed a feature of CubeMaps seams filtering on the faces edges.
So disabling the `unmaskedRenderer` forces engine to use manual seams path which avoids an issue.

Prevent initialize() overwriting textures to null if they are waiting on an asset to be loaded (#1406)

initialize() is called on a material immediately after the placeholder textures are assigned. The source data currently replaces asset id with the actual texture and initialize would clear to null if the data didn't contain the texture. Instead we now also check if it is an asset id, in which case we can wait until the asset is loaded and leave the placeholder texture.

This prevents additional shader compilation calls (because the number of textures on the material changes).

Fix 2D touchend issue (#1218)

This PR fixes annoying issue with 2D elements events.
Reproduce: 
1. Tap on element and keep holding it
2. Tap somewhere else
3. Release element. `Touchend` event doesn't fire then.

It appears because in _handleTouchStart we overwrite _touchedElements, which contains also a previously tapped event.
So instead of replacing, we merge it and then it works in appropriate way.

There is also a more clear solution with Object.assign, but I'm not sure about that, since it's on ES6.

Test project: https://playcanvas.com/project/557165/overview/touch-issue

Support for webglcontextlost (#1119)

This PR implements support for 'webglcontextlost' and 'webglcontextrestored' events. It will reinitialize all WebGL resources managed by the engine including:

* Shaders
* Buffers (both index and vertex)
* Textures
* Render targets
* Transform feedback (this is actually catered for by restoring buffers)

When the context is lost, the pc.Application no longer calls update and render.

The pc.GraphicsDevice now fires events to notify the application that the context has been lost/restored to allow the application to do things like regenerate the contents of render targets, say. The events are: 'devicelost' and 'devicerestored'. So, where necessary, you should be able to do something like:

    this.app.graphicsDevice.on('devicerestored', function () {
        setupRenderTargets();
    });

The pc.GraphicsDevice has been refactored quite significantly. I've tried to group similar operations and then encapsulate those groups in functions. For example:

* All calls to gl.getParameter.
* All calls to gl.getExtension.
* All calls to set WebGL render state.

Allow Timer to use window.performance.now where available (#1064)

The current consencus on timing in the browser seem to suggest the use of window.performance.now() where possible and Date.now() as a fallback, as the former is more precise and the later more performant than new Date.getTime.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12517359/performance-date-now-vs-date-gettime https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30795525/performance-now-vs-date-now https://www.sitepoint.com/discovering-the-high-resolution-time-api/

Fix discrepency in pc.KeyboardEvent documentation (#1061)

In the docs for pc.KeyboardEvent for the `event` param, it is said that it is 'the original browser event that was fired' but the type assigned for it in the docs is `pc.KeyboardEvent`. Unless I'm mistaken, it should be the `KeyboardEvent` object from the web API. This would correspond to the `event` property which has the same description but is typed `KeyboardEvent`.

Merge pull request #969 from MeisterGit/patch-2

Update lightmapper.js for negative scales

Update lightmapper.js for negative scales

If a model has a negative scale (say, for mirroring it) the lightmap size calculation returns 1 instead of a real resolution.

This kills the lightmap.

I updated totalArea to always be positive by applying Math.abs() the scale prior to its calculation, because negatively scaled objects need the same size lightmap as their positively scaled brethren.

-   Fix using wrong cull mode in drawQuadWithShader.
-   Fix clear settings when clearing a depth target.

WebGL2 MSAA RTs and RenderTarget refactor (#877)

New API:
- pc.RenderTarget constructor is changed and now just:
`new pc.RenderTarget(options)`
Device is not needed anymore, colorBuffer is an option. The constructor is backwards compatible though.
- New options (WebGL2):
-- options.samples (int): defines the number of MSAA samples.
-- options.autoResolve (bool): automatically resolve MSAA after rendering (the default is true).
-- options.depthBuffer (pc.Texture): same as colorBuffer, but for depth - put your own texture. Must have PIXELFORMAT_DEPTH or PIXELFORMAT_DEPTHSTENCIL format. Read it back later. Depth and stencil options are then ignored.
- RenderTarget.resolve(color, depth): manually resolve MSAA RT when needed.
refactor events.js, now it avoids allocations as much as possible (90%+) (#876)

Add optional name-parameter to Entity/Graph constructor (#845)

This PR saves lots of coding time by allowing developers to pass the entity name directly in the constructor. This not only minimizes tedious code but also makes its easier for the many that are familiar with Unity and/or porting code from Unity, see [`GameObject` constructor](https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/GameObject-ctor.html).

Please note that this still supports the old **undocumented** API of passing the `pc.Application` to the constructor. The PR is implemented to correctly handle the all use cases. In addition, the PR also documents all parameters (not just the new optional name) for both the `Entity` and `GraphNode` constructors and all exempels have also been updated to the comply with the documented API.

Summary of PR:
- Completely backwards-compatible.
- Full API documentation.
- Well tested!
- New optional APIs:
- - `new pc.Entity(name, app)` (old `new pc.Entity(app)` is still supported!)
- - `new pc.GraphNode(name)`


Please consider this important PR for us. Cheers

Merge branch 'master' into refactor/context-components

* master: (28 commits)
  Tidy up of backwards compatibility code.
  Corrected filenames in dependencies.txt.
  Remove pc.loadPack from the docs since the function doesn't actually exist - it's commented out in the sourcebase.
  Fix
  pc.math.log2 changed to Math.log2 patch
  More conventional DXT5nm swizzling.
  Fixed non-square DDS textures.
  Non-compressed RGBA dds support.
  DXT cubemaps and different IE check.
  Fix
  pc.math.log2
  Added pc.math.log2, because Math.log2 is not supported on IE.
  DXT1/DXT5 DDS support. Normal maps can be packed into DXT5nm (a bit differently swizzled) now.
  Remove pc.ForwardRenderer from the docs. It's internal and should not be considered API.
  Rename light and camera source files. Hide low level camera data structures from the docs since they're no longer considered API.
  Lights and cameras no longer subclass GraphNode.
  Update post effects example to work with updated post effect scripts.
  Bloom shader uniform renames.
  Update extras scripts to latest API. Hide ComponentData and ComponentSystemRegistry from the docs.
  Ensure all live link message types are exposed for Designer.
  ...

Conflicts:
	examples/animation/index.html
	examples/load_model/index.html
	src/framework/components/light/light_component.js
	src/framework/components/light/light_system.js
	src/framework/framework_application.js
	src/framework/framework_pack.js

Add pc.Entity#addComponent()
new pc.Entity() now requires application as argument

With this change you can now call addComponent on an Entity object. This is less verbose and more understandable. (Adding a component to an entity, rather than and an entity to a component system.)

This should be a backwards compatible change as Entity will (temporarily) retrieve the application using the standard canvas id which is used in online play canvas games.
There is a deprecation warning that all new Entities should now be passed the application.
Tidy up of backwards compatibility code.
Remove pc.loadPack from the docs since the function doesn't actually exist - it's commented out in the sourcebase.

pc.Application is altered to include assets, systems, keyboard, mouse, gamepads, touch, etc.

Moved pc.input API into the top level pc namespace.

Move pc.anim API to the global pc namespace.

Merge pull request #92 from guycalledfrank/graphics-fixes2

Graphics fixes 2

Some documentation.
specularAA now also works for old Phong.
Changed naming from modulateMap to mapModulate, fixed brackets, added a few more conditions.

Glossiness is changed once again to be more linear. Glossiness-related bugs are fixed.
Returned back normalMap normalization even with bumpiness = 1.0.
Possible now to select UV channel for AO map with material.aoUvSet (0 or 1). Defaults to 0 now.
Possibility to control color modulation per-map: modulateAmbient, modulateDiffuse, modulateSpecular, modulateEmission.
Gamma correction is now applied for colors so we don't get weird results like "ambient is too bright" etc. Affects material ambient, diffuse, specular and emissive, scene ambient and fog, light colors.
Fixed default toneMapping to be linear (was set to None);
New conserveEnergy parameter can be used to disable energy conservation when mixing diffuse and specular. This is not physically correct, but can be useful if, for example, you don't have an environment map, but want to just add specular highlights without making unaffected areas darker.
Fixed sphereMap conflict with cubeMap on shader compilation.

Migration:
Shininess should be converted to new values using this formula:
Math.max(0.0, Math.min(1.0, (Math.log2(shininess) / 11.0))) * 100
The same formula should be applied to FBX shininess values.

UI:
- specularAA should be moved to Normals section and only be visible when normal map is used.
- AO map UV set selector should be added to AO section.
- Why do we have a separate AO section anyway? Shouldn't it be inside Ambient section?
- modulateAmbient checkbox should be in Ambient section.
- modulateDiffuse in diffuse.
- modulateSpecular in specular.
- modulateEmission in emission.
- conserveEnergy checkbox should be added to Specular section.

Merge pull request #83 from playcanvas/feature/deferred-texture-creation

Deferred texture and framebuffer creation until they are required by the...
Deferred texture and framebuffer creation until they are required by the graphics device.
Fixes, tweaks, better Schlick, per-material specular/fresnel change

Graphics changes.

HDR:
Textures now can be marked HDR by setting .hdr flag on them. This works as a hint to shader constructor. Technically, HDR textures are assumed to be 8-bit RGBM encoded.
If you don't know what RGBM is, read this: http://graphicrants.blogspot.ru/2009/04/rgbm-color-encoding.html (there are some custom precision tweaks in my version though, like using 8 instead of 6 and doing pow(0.5) at encode time)
In short, it allows us to pack HDR image into an ordinary RGBA texture with reasonable precision.
HDR textures aimed to be primarily used for reflections (cube and sphere maps supported) and lightmaps (not supported yet).
Ideally we need Designer to be able to convert HDR images (.hdr, .exr, .dds) to RGBM when importing assets (Unity does it, btw).
In future, engine will be also able to render and correctly filter in-scene cubemaps automatically, with RGBM encoding as well. But still, we need HDR asset importing for things like sky textures.

Tonemapping:
Is an operation of compressing HDR colors into our 0-1 screen. Can simulate human vision or film or whatever. Extremely important for realistic rendering.
It's NOT a post-effect in my version, but instead it is injected into material shaders. Valve did it the same way in Lost Coast, if I remember right. The advantage is that we save a lot of memory and bandwidth by doing it right in shaders, instead of outputting a fat HDR texture (which is not supported on all platforms), then reading it back and writing back tonemapped RGBA8.
The disadvantage is that we can't use true HDR post-effects like Bloom, it needs to be faked LDR-style. I don't think it's a big loss though. When we start going deferred, such effects will be possible, but we need some nice fast forward rendering for all possible platforms in the first place.
Tonemapping is currently a global scene value, like gamma correction. Currently it can be either 0 (no tonemapping) or 1 (Filmic tonemapping http://filmicgames.com/archives/75). More tonamapping operators (2, 3...) can be added later.
No eye adaptation effect yet.

Exposure:
Also a global scene value (should it be per-camera value maybe?) that affects tonemapping.

Prefiltered cubemaps:
Cubemaps with a specific mip chain generated by evaluating BRDF. Allows for environment reflection with variable glossiness in sync with mathematical specular. Due to WebGL limitations, each mip map has to be separate cubemap (we don't have textureCubeLod in PS).
Currently mips must be generated in an offline tool. Later I'll add in-engine generation.
Used for both reflections and ambient diffuse lighting.
Highest mip resolution is locked to 128x128 to simplify things (same in UE4, btw). Rarely higher res is needed, because higher number of in-scene cubemaps and fast filter time is more important.
Can be set to a material using new parameters:
prefilteredCube128
prefilteredCube64
prefilteredCube32
prefilteredCube16
prefilteredCube8
prefilteredCube4
Number means face resolution. If any of the cubemaps are not set, prefiltered stuff won't work, all are required.
4x4 is the lowest, because WebGL doesn't perform bilinear interpolation between cubemap faces, and lower res looks glitchy.
Due to this limitation, prefiltered cubemaps must be also processed with this technique to hide any seams: http://the-witness.net/news/2012/02/seamless-cube-map-filtering/
Shaders then read them assuming it is applied.

Skybox:
- Can be now created with cubemap as parameter instead of 6 asset ids;
- Can be HDR (if HDR cubemap is used);
- Shader code moved to shaderChunks.

Ambient occlusion map (baked):
Can be specified per-material. Currently uses lightmap UVs (should be later be able to choose). Changes ambient color by multiplying it.

Glossiness:
- now not just a "specular power" from 0 to 100, but defines a range from full hemisphere to mirror reflection (that is more meaningful). Blinn-Phong and prefiltered cubemaps are tweaked this way. Old Phong works as before.

Specular anti-aliasing:
Based on Toksvig: http://www.nvidia.com/object/mipmapping_normal_maps.html
Can be enabled with new specularAA material flag. Only works for Blinn-Phong.

Blending maps with colors:
Colors (diffuse, specular, emissive) and single float parameters (gloss, opacity) now can be multiplied by corresponding maps. This allows users to do easy tweaks, like darken albedo, reduce gloss a bit etc.
The behaviour is activated per-material by blendMapsWithColors flag, which is now true by default.
It probably requires a migration to set all colors/floats to white/one in packs where texture overrides where used, so they won't break after change.

Optimizations:
- Color/float multipliers are omitted from shader if set to white/one, degenerating to simple texture-only mode (saving uniforms/ALU);
- "Bumpiness" parameter code is removed from shader if set to 1 (avoiding normalize in PS/reducing uniforms).

Fixes:
- fixed reflection not being visible in some cases when there are no lights.

branch : feature/json-loader

Resource Requests are not typed and cache hits only occur if type matches

You can define an optional Type value on a ResourceRequest, if you do, values in the cache will be checked against this type, and if they don't match the cache value is not sued.
This prevents ImageRequests and TextureRequests getting confused in the cache. Though it means they will overwrite each other in the cache...
Fixes skyboxes

If a model component had an asset on it, which was then deleted, when you load the designer it has an empty asset slot, on setting a new asset there was a crash in the engine. I've fixed this.

branch : stable
Correctly complete requests that are loaded from cache

Added canonical identifiers and caching to reosurce loader
Loading an asset resource will register values into a url -> file hash map which is then used to generate canonical identifiers for resources when they are loaded.
So now files with identical hashes are loaded from the same source.
Also the ResourceLoader now stores the instances of resources once they are loaded and opened. Subsequent requests for the same resource will return the original resource, or optionally for the resource a clone of the resource.
Currently only model resources return a clone.

Model loader now ignores texture transforms on the texture. Instead they are taken from a material's parameters.
Scene#setGlobalAmbient now also accepts separate r, g and b parameters.
Global ambient now works when there are no lights enabled.
Optimized some code generation for the Phong shader generator, especially for the case when no lights are enabled.

Entity loading is now 2 passes, first create all Entities and build the hierarchy. Then create all the components once the hierarchy is completed.
OpenEntityMessages now send the complete hierarchy of entities instead of a flat list, this means we no longer use the old EntityRequest code for opening entities. Everything goes through PackRequestHandler.openPack/openEntity.
Separate body2d collision into separate collisionrect component, will add a collisioncircle component next

Always render body2d components in x/z plane.
Body2d components don't handle parent transforms very well. Probably best to ensure there are no parent transforms when using them

Body2d rendering is done from local transform
If the Body2D component is rendered from the world transform, parent transforms can rotate it in a dimension that is irrelevant for 2D
Add setDebugRender() to Body2d component system
Added Body2d Component System for 2D physics

Added WebSocket wrapper pc.net.Socket
Changed to building with ECMAScript 5 to support getters for WebSocket wrapper

Updated framework to support new scene-managed lighting system.

All ComponentSystem have an initialize() method now
If it is present the initialize() method will be called immediately after a pack is loaded and passed the pack. This enables ComponentSystems to initialize after the pack is completely loaded but before the first update
e.g. Scripts call the script initialize() method and also register all instances
AudioSource activates any sounds that should be playing
This prevents initialization occuring in an adhoc fashion as the data is loaded which happens if you place initialization code in onSetX methods
Moved static global ambient LightNode functions to the pc.scene.Scene API as prototype functions.
Moved light management into pc.scene.Scene, removing functions pc.scene.LightNode#getNumEnabled and pc.scene.LightNode#dispatch. Lighting can now only work if a scene is used.

MouseEvent object now has x,y fields instead of offsetX, offsetY.
MouseEvent object no longer has positionX, positionY fields.
[FIX] hierarchy is synced in Application.start() before first update tick

Added tag v0.11.1 for changeset 79fb213469f9

--HG--
branch : stable

Remove reliance on constructor.name in shape as it is stripped away in compiled code.

Added Shape.type to instance with a value from pc.shape.Type enumeration

Added tag v0.11.0 for changeset 54cbc84ec1c8

--HG--
branch : stable

Fixed optional argument initialization for camera frameBegin.
Some more docs for MeshNode.
Remove excess log output from livelink messages

New pc.net.OAuth() and pc.net.Http() classes

Refactored net_http so that there is now a pc.net.Http class and a default instance of this is created at pc.net.http. So no compatability issues.

Added pc.net.OAuth which sub-classes pc.net.Http and can be used to access resources that require OAuth 2.0 authentication. Supports the same get/post/put/delete methods as Http, but adds a refreshAccessToken() method which is used to get a new valid access token. Uses client-side cookies for authentication.
A 401 response will automatically trigger an refresh of the access token and the request will be resent.
[FIX] pc.URI.getQuery() returns correct value when the query string is empty
Added them removed start of oauth handling in pc.net.http
Corrected pc.scene.SubMesh docs which were incorrectly categorized as pc.graph.

[FIX] ResourceBatch handles errors a little more gracefully.
ResourceBatch will fire error callback when a resource fails, and also call error callback of parent. Parent ResourceBatch will still call success callback when it completes though

[FIX] Errors in child resource requests bubble up to parent
[FIX] Failed resource requests are cleared from the ResourceLoader so repeated requests are correctly made
Bind pick target before clearing it.
Picker now expects Y coord to be with reference to a bottom left origin.
[FIX] Remove references to constructor.name in ResourceRequest.

Added tag v0.10.0 for changeset 0015276ac687

--HG--
branch : stable

Switched pc.math.mat* to use Array instead of Float32Array for performance.
Removed indentity member of pc.math.mat4.
pc.math.mat*.create now create the identity matrix by default rather than an undefined matrix.
Fixed framework to work without the GraphManager.
Removed graph manager from scene API.

Handle errors in net_http a little better.
Cross domain errors should fire error callback, as should send exceptions
Fixed tests for net_http

Fixed the livelink tests.
